Advantages of gene level associations

Reduced multiple testing burden (from 10e6 to 10e4)
The function of genes are much better annotated than SNPs
Validation in other model systems is possible
Reverse causality issues is less problematic because disease status doesn’t affect germline genetic markers
It provides the direction of effects, i.e. whether up or down regulation of a gene - increases the risk of a disease
The candidate causal gene is a good target for drug development

section: Leeuw et al’s “reformulated null hypothesis”
text:
Leeuw et al’s “reformulated null hypothesis”
\[  Y = \beta ~ T +  \epsilon_\text{twas} \] \[  T = \sum_k \gamma_k ~ X_k \]
\[H_0\!:~ \beta = 0\]

Leeuw et al claim that this is equivalent to
\[H_0\!:~ \hat\beta  = 0\]


This is not hypothesis testing is done. {\(\hat\beta=0\)} is an event with probability 0.


Premise is wrong, and the conclusion is wrong
We can dismiss the report that error in prediction invalidates *WAS

section: Take home message
text:
Take home message





Standard TWAS can yield inflated p-values when the trait is highly polygenic
Inflation can be corrected by simply using the noncentral χ2 distribution when calculating the p-values
Error in prediction does not cause inflation (under reasonable assumptions)
Noisy predictors can be used which will reduce false negatives, as long as the type I error is controlled

section: Leeuws et al claim that error in variable causes inflation
text:
Leeuws et al claim that error in variable causes inflation


We want to regress \(Y\) on \(T\) \[  Y = \beta ~ T +  \epsilon_\text{twas} \]
\[  T = \sum_k \gamma_k ~ X_k \]
But we only have the noisy version of \(T\), \(\tilde{T} = \sum_k \tilde{\gamma}_k ~ X_k\) and we end up regressing \(Y\) on \(\tilde{T}\)

\[  Y = \beta ~ \tilde{T} +  \tilde\epsilon \]
\[  \tilde{T} = \sum_k \tilde{\gamma}_k ~ X_k \]

section: But error in variables literature contradicts that claim
text:
But error in variables literature contradicts that claim
 

No inflation when using noisy explanatory variables



There is attenuation bias \[| E \hat\beta | < |\beta|\]

section: What does the inflation factor \(\Phi\) look like
text:
What does the inflation factor \(\Phi\) look like
\[ E \chi^2 \propto N h^2 \frac{1}{M} ?\]


if we do the math, we get \[ E \chi^2 \approx
1 +  N ~ h^2 ~\frac{\tilde\gamma' \cdot \Sigma^2  \cdot \tilde\gamma}{\tilde\gamma' \cdot  \Sigma  \cdot \tilde\gamma} \frac{1}{M} \]
let’s define \(\Phi\) \[ \Phi  = \frac{\tilde\gamma' \cdot \Sigma^2  \cdot \tilde\gamma}{\tilde\gamma' \cdot  \Sigma  \cdot \tilde\gamma} \frac{1}{M}\]
\(\frac{1}{M} \le \Phi \le 1\)
lower bound attained when SNPs are independent
upper bound attained when SNPs are perfectly correlated
\(\Phi = \frac{\text{tr}(\Sigma^2)}{M^2}\) if mediator is also polygenic

section: Polygenic Target Trait Y & Noisy Mediator
text:
Polygenic Target Trait Y & Noisy Mediator
\[\begin{align}
  Y &= \beta \cdot T + \sum_k X_k \cdot \delta_k + \epsilon \\
  T &= \sum_k \gamma_k \cdot X_k \\
  \tilde{T} &= \sum_k (\gamma_k + e_{\gamma,k}) \cdot X_k
\end{align}
\]
 
\[E~\chi^2_\text{twas} \approx 1  + N ~h^2_\delta ~ \Phi(\text{gene})\]

section: TWAS χ2 Statistic with Polygenic Y & Noisy Mediator
text:
TWAS χ2 Statistic with Polygenic Y & Noisy Mediator
\[E~\chi^2_\text{twas} \approx 1  + N ~h^2_\delta ~ \frac{\Phi(\text{gene})}{1 - \beta^2\tau^2} +  N ~ \frac{\beta^2 }{1 - \beta^2\tau^2}~\tau^2\]
\[\tau^2 = \text{signal to noise ratio}\] \[ = \text{precision} = \frac{\text{var}(T)}{\text{var}(\tilde{T})}\]

Ttilde = X %*% (gamma + e)
Y = beta * Ttilde + etwas
fit = lm(Y ~ Ttilde)

No inflation

\[ \text{where } \Phi_1  = \frac{\tilde\gamma' \cdot \Sigma^2  \cdot \tilde\gamma}{\tilde\gamma' \cdot  \Sigma  \cdot \tilde\gamma}  \]


when SNPs are independent, \(\Phi_1 = 1\) so that \(~~~E \chi^2 = 1 + N h^2 \frac{1}{M}\) pretty close to our guess
